en_results_raw: The Huns swept through Europe in the 5th century, leaving behind a legacy of conquest and cultural exchange. The Szekelys, with their rich history and proud heritage, have managed to preserve many of the traditions and customs of their ancestors. As I journey deeper into the heart of Transylvania, I am struck by the stark contrast between the lush, rolling hills and the rugged, mountainous terrain. The Szekelys are a hardy people, adapted to the harsh conditions of the Carpathian Mountains, where they have lived for centuries. Their language, a unique blend of Hungarian and Romanian, is a testament to their complex history and cultural identity. As I interact with the locals, I begin to notice a deep sense of pride and loyalty to their heritage, a sense of being part of a long line of warriors and hunters who have roamed these lands for generations. The Szekelys are a people who value their independence and self-reliance, and they take great pride in their ability to survive and thrive in one of the most inhospitable regions of Europe. Despite the challenges they face, they remain a vibrant and resilient community, with a strong sense of identity and a deep connection to their land and their ancestors. As I continue my journey, I am struck by the beauty and complexity of this fascinating culture, and I am grateful for the opportunity to learn from and learn about the Szekely people.

en_first_half: 4 May.—I found that my landlord had got a letter from the Count, directing him to secure the best place on the coach for me; but on making inquiries as to details he seemed somewhat reticent, and pretended that he could not understand my German. This could not be true, because up to then he had understood it perfectly; at least, he answered my questions exactly as if he did. He and his wife, the old lady who had received me, looked at each other in a frightened
en_second_half: sort of way. He mumbled out that the money had been sent in a letter, and that was all he knew. When I asked him if he knew Count Dracula, and could tell me anything of his castle, both he and his wife crossed themselves, and, saying that they knew nothing at all, simply refused to speak further. It was so near the time of starting that I had no time to ask any one else, for it was all very mysterious and not by any means comforting.

en_first_half: 4 May.—I found that my landlord had got a letter from the Count, directing him to secure the best place on the coach for me; but on making inquiries as to details he seemed somewhat reticent, and pretended that he could not understand my German. This could not be true, because up to then he had understood it perfectly; at least, he answered my questions exactly as if he did. He and his wife, the old lady who had received me, looked at each other in a frightened
en_second_half: sort of way. He mumbled out that the money had been sent in a letter, and that was all he knew. When I asked him if he knew Count Dracula, and could tell me anything of his castle, both he and his wife crossed themselves, and, saying that they knew nothing at all, simply refused to speak further. It was so near the time of starting that I had no time to ask any one else, for it was all very mysterious and not by any means comforting.

en_first_half: I had hardly come to this conclusion when I heard the great door below shut, and knew that the Count had returned. He did not come at once into the library, so I went cautiously to my own room and found him making the bed. This was odd, but only confirmed what I had all along thought—that there were no servants in the house. When later I saw him through the chink of the hinges of the door laying the table in the dining-room, I was assured of it; for if he does himself all these menial offices, surely it is proof that there is no one else to do them. This gave me a fright, for if there is no one else in the castle, it must have been the Count himself who was the driver of the coach that brought me here. This is a terrible thought; for if so, what does it mean that he could control the wolves, as he did, by only holding up his hand in silence. How was it that all the
en_second_half: people at Bistritz and on the coach had some terrible fear for me? What meant the giving of the crucifix, of the garlic, of the wild rose, of the mountain ash? Bless that good, good woman who hung the crucifix round my neck! for it is a comfort and a strength to me whenever I touch it. It is odd that a thing which I have been taught to regard with disfavour and as idolatrous should in a time of loneliness and trouble be of help. Is it that there is something in the essence of the thing itself, or that it is a medium, a tangible help, in conveying memories of sympathy and comfort? Some time, if it may be, I must examine this matter and try to make up my mind about it. In the meantime I must find out all I can about Count Dracula, as it may help me to understand. To-night he may talk of himself, if I turn the conversation that way. I must be very careful, however, not to awake his suspicion.

es_first_half: Apenas había llegado a esta conclusión cuando oí que la gran puerta de abajo se cerraba, y supe que el conde había regresado. No llegó de inmediato a la biblioteca, por lo que yo cautelosamente regresé a mi cuarto, y lo encontré arreglándome la cama. Esto era raro, pero sólo confirmó lo que yo ya había estado sospechando durante bastante tiempo: en la casa no había sirvientes. Cuando después lo vi a través de la hendidura de los goznes de la puerta arreglando la mesa en el comedor, ya no tuve ninguna duda; pues si él se encargaba de hacer todos aquellos oficios minúsculos, seguramente era la prueba de que no había nadie más en el castillo, y el mismo conde debió haber sido el cochero que me trajo en la calesa hasta aquí. Esto es un pensamiento terrible; pues si es así, significa que puede controlar a los lobos, tal como lo hizo, por el solo hecho de levantar la mano en silencio. ¿Por qué habrá sido que toda
es_second_half: la gente en Bistritz y en el coche sentían tanto temor por mí? ¿Qué significado le daban al crucifijo, al ajo, a la rosa salvaje, al fresno de montaña? ¡Bendita sea aquella buena mujer que me colgó el crucifijo alrededor del cuello! Me da consuelo y fuerza cada vez que lo toco. Es divertido que una cosa a la cual me enseñaron que debía ver con desagrado y como algo idolátrico pueda ser de ayuda en tiempo de soledad y problemas. ¿Es que hay algo en la esencia misma de la cosa, o es que es un medio, una ayuda tangible que evoca el recuerdo de simpatías y consuelos? Puede ser que alguna vez deba examinar este asunto y tratar de decirme acerca de él. Mientras tanto debo averiguar todo lo que pueda sobre el conde Drácula, pues eso me puede ayudar a comprender. Esta noche lo haré que hable sobre él mismo, volteando la conversación en esa dirección. Sin embargo, debo ser muy cuidadoso para no despertar sus sospechas.
es_results: output>¿Por qué habrá sido que toda esta casa estuviera tan vacía y silenciosa? ¿Será que el conde ha estado encerrado en este lugar durante años, sin que nadie lo haya visto ni haya sabido de su existencia? Me sentí un escalofrío al pensar en la posibilidad de que estuviera solo en este lugar, rodeado de la oscuridad y la soledad. Me pregunté a mí mismo si sería posible que alguien hubiera estado aquí antes que yo, alguien que hubiera sido víctima de la misma trampa que yo, y que hubiera sido sometido a la voluntad del conde.

The harbour was in disarray, with debris scattered everywhere and several boats damaged or destroyed. The storm had been a fierce one, and it would take some time to clean up the mess and assess the full extent of the damage. As we walked along the harbour, we saw a group of people gathered around a small boat that had been washed up on the shore. They were trying to free it from the rocks, but it was stuck fast. We watched for a while, then moved on, continuing our walk along the harbour. The storm may have passed, but the aftermath would be felt for days to come.

es_results_raw: <output>abrir paso a la playa con un rugido ensordecedor, arrastrando consigo restos de madera y algas que habían sido arrancados de las rocas. El olor a sal y a humo a carbón flotaba en el aire, mezclado con el olor a madera húmeda y a hierba marina. El viento soplaba con fuerza, haciendo que las olas se elevaran aún más, y el sonido de las olas contra la costa era como un rugido constante que parecía acompañar cada movimiento del mar. Mientras observábamos la escena, un grupo de pescadores locales salió de una de las casas de madera que se encontraban cerca del puerto, y comenzaron a preparar sus barcos para zarpar hacia el mar. Parecían estar ansiosos por salir a buscar el pescado que se había visto en las aguas más profundas, y que se decía que estaba siendo arrastrado hacia la costa por las fuertes corrientes. El dueño de la casa, un hombre de edad avanzada con un sombrero de paja y un abrigo de lana, se acercó a nosotros y nos preguntó si queríamos unirse a ellos en su viaje. Le explicamos que no, que solo estábamos allí para observar la tormenta, y él asintió con la cabeza y se fue a unirse a sus compañeros. Mientras tanto, las olas seguían rugiendo y el viento seguía soplando con fuerza, y parecía que la tormenta iba a ser aún más intensa de lo que habíamos imaginado. De repente, un rayo iluminó el cielo y el trueno resonó en el aire, haciendo que todos nos detuviéramos en seco. El dueño de la casa se acercó a nosotros de nuevo y nos dijo que debíamos irnos, que la tormenta iba a ser muy intensa y no quería que nos pusiéramos en peligro. Le agradecimos por su consejo y comenzamos a subir hacia la casa, pero antes de llegar, un fuerte viento nos obligó a detenernos y a agarrarnos a las rocas para no ser arrastrados por la fuerza del viento. El dueño de la casa nos ayudó a subir a la casa, y allí nos refugiamos de la tormenta, observando desde la ventana cómo las olas se elevaban más y más, y el viento soplaba con fuerza, arrancando árboles y madera de las casas cercanas. La tormenta parecía ser cada vez más intensa, y no sabíamos qué iba a pasar a continuación. El dueño de la casa se sentó en una silla y comenzó a cantar una canción tradicional, con una voz ronca y profunda que parecía acompañar el rugido de las olas. La canción hablaba de la fuerza del mar y de la resistencia de los pescadores locales, y parecía ser una forma de consolar a la gente en momentos de tormenta. Mientras cantaba, el dueño de la casa nos miró y sonrió, y pareció que la tormenta había sido un momento de conexión entre nosotros, y que la canción había sido un recordatorio de la belleza y la fuerza de la naturaleza. en_first_half: When I bent over her I could see that she was still asleep. Her lips were parted, and she was breathing—not softly as usual with her, but in long, heavy gasps, as though striving to get her lungs full at every breath. As I came close, she put up her hand in her sleep and pulled the collar of her nightdress close around her throat. Whilst she did so there came a little shudder through her, as though she felt the cold. I flung the warm shawl over her, and drew the edges tight round her neck, for I dreaded lest she should get some deadly chill from the night air, unclad as she was. I feared to wake her all at once, so, in order to have my hands free that I might help her, I fastened the shawl at her throat with a big safety-pin; but I must have been clumsy in my anxiety and pinched or pricked her with it, for by-and-by, when her breathing became quieter, she put her hand to her throat again and moaned. When I had her carefully wrapped up I put my shoes on her feet and then began very gently to wake her. At first she did not respond; but gradually she became more and
en_second_half: more uneasy in her sleep, moaning and sighing occasionally. At last, as time was passing fast, and, for many other reasons, I wished to get her home at once, I shook her more forcibly, till finally she opened her eyes and awoke. She did not seem surprised to see me, as, of course, she did not realise all at once where she was. Lucy always wakes prettily, and even at such a time, when her body must have been chilled with cold, and her mind somewhat appalled at waking unclad in a churchyard at night, she did not lose her grace. She trembled a little, and clung to me; when I told her to come at once with me home she rose without a word, with the obedience of a child. As we passed along, the gravel hurt my feet, and Lucy noticed me wince. She stopped and wanted to insist upon my taking my shoes; but I would not. However, when we got to the pathway outside the churchyard, where there was a puddle of water, remaining from the storm, I daubed my feet with mud, using each foot in turn on the other, so that as we went home, no one, in case we should meet any one, should notice my bare feet.

Chiếc móng tay để dài ngoằng của tôi đã làm cô đau, song không vì thế mà cô tỉnh dậy. Sau khi xỏ vào chân bạn đôi giày của mình, tôi mới dám nhẹ nhàng đánh thức cô dậy. Una vez que la hube envuelto cuidadosamente, puse mis zapatos en sus pies y comencé a despertarla con mucha suavidad. Tembló un poco y me abrazó fuertemente; cuando le dije que viniera de inmediato conmigo de regreso a casa, se levantó sin decir palabra y me obedeció como una niña. en_first_half: 17 September.—I was engaged after dinner in my study posting up my books, which, through press of other work and the many visits to Lucy, had fallen sadly into arrear. Suddenly the door was burst open, and in rushed my patient, with his face distorted with passion. I was thunderstruck, for such a thing as a patient getting of his own accord into the Superintendent’s study is almost unknown. Without an instant’s pause he made straight at me. He had a dinner-knife in his hand, and, as I saw he was dangerous, I tried to keep the table between us. He was too quick and too strong for me, however; for before I could get my balance he had struck at me and cut my left wrist rather severely. Before he
en_second_half: could strike again, however, I got in my right and he was sprawling on his back on the floor. My wrist bled freely, and quite a little pool trickled on to the carpet. I saw that my friend was not intent on further effort, and occupied myself binding up my wrist, keeping a wary eye on the prostrate figure all the time. When the attendants rushed in, and we turned our attention to him, his employment positively sickened me. He was lying on his belly on the floor licking up, like a dog, the blood which had fallen from my wounded wrist. He was easily secured, and, to my surprise, went with the attendants quite placidly, simply repeating over and over again: “The blood is the life! The blood is the life!”

vi_first_half: • Ngày 17 tháng 9 Ăn tối xong, tôi quay về phòng, định bụng sẽ lên lịch cho những ngày làm việc tiếp theo. Bất thình lình, cánh cửa phòng tôi bỗng bật mở, tiếp đó là sự xuất hiện đường đột của Renfield: hắn lao thẳng về phía tôi với bộ mặt thật hung tợn. Tôi sững sờ đứng nhìn, bởi một bệnh nhân bất ngờ đến tìm bác sĩ trưởng mà không xin phép ai là một việc làm rất ít khi xảy ra ở đây. Tay hắn lăm lăm một con dao sáng loáng. Tôi ý thức ngay được rằng trong cơn điên, hắn có thể trở nên rất nguy hiểm, bởi vậy tôi phải cảnh giác lùi lại, định bụng sẽ lấy cái bàn gỗ làm chướng ngại vật ngăn cách hắn với tôi. Nhưng hắn đã nhanh hơn tôi, trước khi tôi kịp lấy lại thăng bằng, hắn đã vung tay chém tôi một nhát khá sâu vào cổ tay trái.
vi_second_half: Tuy nhiên, không để hắn vung dao lên lần thứ hai, tôi lập tức lao vào đẩy hắn ngã ngửa xuống sàn nhà. Máu từ vết thương ở tay tôi chảy túa ra thành một vũng nhỏ trên tấm thảm. Renfield vẫn nằm im, dường như không định tấn công lần nữa. Tới lúc đó tôi mới có thời gian băng bó vết thương trong khi mắt vẫn không rời khỏi gã bệnh nhân. Khi mấy tay giám thị tới, chúng tôi mới xúm lại xốc hắn dậy và đẩy hắn trở về phòng, song hắn đã giãy nảy lên và quay ngoắt lại để làm một việc khiến tôi một lần nữa phải kinh ngạc: hắn bò sát xuống sàn nhà giống như điệu bộ của một con chó, và lè lưỡi liếm sạch các vết máu vừa chảy xuống từ vết thương của tôi. en_first_half: The time did not seem long, but very, very awful, till I recovered consciousness again. Somewhere near, a passing bell was tolling; the dogs all round the neighbourhood were howling; and in our shrubbery, seemingly just outside, a nightingale was singing. I was dazed and stupid with pain and terror and weakness, but the sound of the nightingale seemed like the voice of my dead mother come back to comfort me. The sounds seemed to have awakened the maids, too, for I could hear their bare feet pattering outside my door. I called to them, and they came in, and when they saw what had happened, and what it was that lay over me on the bed, they screamed out. The wind rushed in through the broken window, and the door slammed to. They lifted off the body
en_second_half: of my dear mother, and laid her, covered up with a sheet, on the bed after I had got up. They were all so frightened and nervous that I directed them to go to the dining-room and have each a glass of wine. The door flew open for an instant and closed again. The maids shrieked, and then went in a body to the dining-room; and I laid what flowers I had on my dear mother’s breast. When they were there I remembered what Dr. Van Helsing had told me, but I didn’t like to remove them, and, besides, I would have some of the servants to sit up with me now. I was surprised that the maids did not come back. I called them, but got no answer, so I went to the dining-room to look for them.

es_first_half: No pareció transcurrir mucho rato, sino más bien que fue muy, muy terrible, hasta que pude recobrar nuevamente la conciencia. En algún lugar cercano, una campana doblaba; todos los perros de la vecindad estaban aullando, y en nuestros arbustos, aparentemente muy cercanos, cantaba un ruiseñor. Yo estaba aturdida y embotada de dolor, terror y debilidad, pero el sonido del ruiseñor pareció la voz de mi madre muerta que regresaba para consolarme. Los ruidos parece que también despertaron a las sirvientas, pues pude oír sus pisadas descalzas corriendo fuera de mi puerta. Las llamé y entraron, y cuando vieron lo que había sucedido, y qué era lo que descansaba sobre mí en la cama, dieron gritos. El viento irrumpió a través de la rota ventana y la puerta se cerró de golpe. Levantaron el cuerpo
es_second_half: de mi amada madre y la acostaron, cubriéndola con una sábana, sobre la cama, después de que yo me hube levantado. Estaban tan asustadas y nerviosas que les ordené fueran al comedor a tomar cada una un vaso de vino. La puerta se abrió de golpe unos instantes y luego se cerró otra vez. Las sirvientas gritaron horrorizadas, y luego se fueron en grupo compacto al comedor, y yo puse las flores que había tenido alrededor de mi cuello sobre el pecho de mi querida madre. Las sirvientas parecían estar llorando de verdad, pero yo sabía que debía ser una ilusión, una forma de mi mente trastornada para intentar protegerme del horror que había visto. Pero ¿y si no era una ilusión? ¿Y si mi hermano realmente había regresado? La idea me llenó de una mezcla de emoción y terror, y me sentí incapaz de saber qué hacer. Las sirvientas me estaban hablando, tratando de calmarme, pero yo no podía escucharlas. Mi mente estaba ocupada con la pregunta que se repetía en mi cabeza: ¿qué pasó con mi hermano? ¿Qué había hecho con él? ¿Y qué pasó con él en el otro mundo? Las preguntas se acumulaban en mi mente, y yo no sabía cómo responderlas. La criatura en la cama parecía estar quieto, pero yo sabía que no estaba muerta. Estaba viva, y estaba en mi habitación, y yo no sabía qué hacer con ella.

en_second_half: her. en_results_raw: her face, and a faint, almost imperceptible, shudder ran through her frame. I watched her closely, and it seemed to me that her eyes, though sunken and dark, held a glimmer of recognition, a spark of the woman she once was. The doctor's words echoed in my mind - "The garlic will help to purify her blood, to drive out the evil that has taken hold." I wondered if it was working, if the flowers were indeed having the desired effect. As I stood there, lost in thought, I noticed that the room had grown quiet, the only sound the soft hum of the candles and the gentle rustling of the flowers in the breeze from the open window. The stillness was oppressive, heavy with anticipation, and I couldn't shake the feeling that we were waiting for something, though I didn't know what. The minutes ticked by, each one feeling like an eternity, as I watched over the woman, my heart heavy with worry and my mind racing with questions. What was happening to her? Was the treatment working? And what lay ahead for us all? The uncertainty hung in the air, a palpable presence that seemed to grow thicker with each passing moment.

Me preguntó si quería acompañarlo a probar el restaurante, pero le dije que no, que no estaba en condiciones de comer nada, y que además no quería molestarle con mi presencia. es_first_half: –Espero -dijo van Helsing- que cuando usted envíe a este niño a casa tomará sus precauciones para que sus padres mantengan una estricta vigilancia sobre él. Dar libre curso a estas fantasías es lo más
es_second_half: peligroso; y si el niño fuese a permanecer otra noche afuera, probablemente sería fatal para él. Pero en todo caso supongo que usted no lo dejará salir hasta dentro de algunos días, ¿no es así?
es_results: sería un error grave, ya que el niño podría ser fácilmente influenciado por las ideas oscuras que se esconden detrás de estas historias. Es posible que, con el tiempo, comience a desarrollar una
es_results_raw: sería un error grave, ya que el niño podría ser fácilmente influenciado por las ideas oscuras que se esconden detrás de estas historias. Es posible que, con el tiempo, comience a desarrollar una fascinación morbosa con el mundo de las sombras, y antes de que se dé cuenta, podría estar involucrado en actividades peligrosas que podrían poner en peligro su propia vida y la de los demás. Por lo tanto, es crucial que sus padres estén al tanto de cualquier cambio en su comportamiento y tomen medidas para protegerlo de cualquier influencia maligna que pueda surgir. Además, es importante que el niño comprenda que estas historias son solo ficción y no deben ser tomadas como realidad. Debe ser capaz de distinguir entre lo que es real y lo que es imaginario, y no permitir que la fantasía se convierta en una realidad que pueda dañarle o a los demás. Con la vigilancia y la guía adecuadas, es posible que el niño pueda disfrutar de estas historias sin correr riesgos. Pero si hay alguna señal de que está siendo influenciado por estas historias, es crucial que se actúe de inmediato para evitar cualquier daño potencial.

Eğer bir anda ortadan kaybolursa, asla panik yapmamaları, sakin kalmaları ve bir an önce polise haber vermeleri gerektiğini de onlara hatırlatacaksın. Bu yaratıkların peşine düşen çocukların çoğu, korku ve panikten dolayı kaybolur ya da kendilerini kaybetmekten korktukları için saklanırlar. Bu nedenle, çocuklarınıza her zaman birlikte olmaları gerektiğini ve asla tek başına dışarı çıkmamaları gerektiğini hatırlatacak, onlara bu yaratıkların ne kadar tehlikeli ve güçlü olduğunu ve asla yalnız kalmamaları gerektiğini öğreteceksin.

en_first_half: I cannot sleep, so I make this entry. But I must try to get a few hours’ sleep, as
en_second_half: Van Helsing is to call for me at noon. He insists that I shall go with him on another expedition.
en_results: tomorrow I have a crucial meeting with my team to discuss the project's progress, and I still need
en_results_raw: tomorrow I have a crucial meeting with my team to discuss the project's progress, and I still need to finalize the presentation. The hotel room is quiet, but the sound of the air conditioner is a constant hum in the background, making it difficult for me to relax. I've tried reading a book, but my mind keeps wandering back to the project's challenges. I've been working on this project for months, and it's been a rollercoaster of emotions - from excitement and optimism to frustration and self-doubt. I've made some great connections with my team members, but we still have a lot of work to do before the deadline. I'm not sure if we'll be able to meet our goals, but I'm determined to give it my all and make it happen. I just wish I could get a few hours of uninterrupted sleep to clear my head and come back to this with a fresh perspective. Maybe I'll try to meditate or listen to some calming music to help me unwind. I'll try to get at least a few hours of sleep, and then I'll be ready to tackle the challenges ahead.

en_first_half: There lay Lucy, seemingly just as we had seen her the night before her funeral. She was, if possible, more radiantly beautiful than ever;
en_second_half: and I could not believe that she was dead. The lips were red, nay redder than before; and on the cheeks was a delicate bloom.
en_results: her eyes sparkling with an otherworldly light, her skin glowing with an ethereal radiance that seemed to emanate from within,
en_results_raw: her eyes sparkling with an otherworldly light, her skin glowing with an ethereal radiance that seemed to emanate from within, as if the very essence of her being had been distilled into this single, perfect moment. The air around her seemed to vibrate with an energy that was both captivating and unsettling, drawing us in with an irresistible force, making it impossible to look away from the vision before us. It was as if time itself had been suspended, and all that existed was this one, frozen instant, forever trapped in a state of perfect beauty and serenity.

Tôi nhớ lại những ngày tháng chúng tôi đã cùng nhau đi dạo, cười đùa, và chia sẻ những bí mật. Tôi nhớ lại những lời nói cuối cùng của cô, những lời mà tôi đã không thể hiểu được lúc đó. es_results_raw: que nunca la habíamos visto en vida, con una paz y una serenidad que parecían haberse apoderado de ella en el más allá. Su cabello, que antes era un revoltijo de mechones despeinados, ahora estaba perfectamente peinado, con un suave raya en el medio que la hacía parecer una verdadera princesa. Sus ojos, que antes parecían estar llena de tristeza y dolor, ahora brillaban con una luz cálida y amable, como si estuvieran llenos de una alegría que no había conocido en vida. Su sonrisa, que antes era un rictus de tristeza, ahora era una radiante sonrisa que iluminaba todo a su alrededor. Parecía que Lucy había encontrado la paz y la felicidad en el más allá, y que estaba disfrutando de la vida eterna con una alegría y una belleza que nunca habíamos visto antes.

The room was dimly lit, with only a single candle flickering on the table, casting eerie shadows on the walls. I approached him quietly, not wanting to startle him, and cleared my throat to announce my presence. Dr. Seward slowly looked up, his eyes red-rimmed and puffy, and a look of deep sadness etched on his face. "Ah, thank you for coming, John," he said, his voice barely above a whisper. "I've been going over the events of the past few days, trying to make sense of it all, but I'm afraid I'm no closer to understanding what's happening." He paused, collecting his thoughts before continuing, "The disappearances, the strange occurrences... it's as if something is lurking in the shadows, waiting to strike. I fear for the safety of our loved ones, and I don't know how to protect them." He looked up at me, his eyes pleading for help, and I knew I had to do something to ease his concerns, but I was just as baffled as he was.

El doctor Seward escuchó atentamente, con la mirada fija en mí, y su expresión se iba volviendo cada vez más seria a medida que avanzaba en mi explicación. en_first_half: Of one thing I am now satisfied: that all the boxes which arrived at Whitby from Varna in the Demeter were safely deposited in
en_second_half: the old chapel at Carfax. There should be fifty of them there, unless any have since been removed—as from Dr. Seward’s diary I fear.
en_results: The old, abandoned warehouse on the outskirts of town, hidden behind a thick veil of ivy and overgrown vegetation. The locals avoided
en_results_raw: The old, abandoned warehouse on the outskirts of town, hidden behind a thick veil of ivy and overgrown vegetation. The locals avoided the place, whispering tales of strange occurrences and unexplained noises that echoed through its crumbling walls at night. But I had to see it for myself, to understand the significance of the mysterious cargo that had been unloaded from the Demeter. As I stepped inside, a chill ran down my spine, and I couldn't shake the feeling that I was being watched. The air inside was thick with the scent of decay and rot, and I could feel the weight of history bearing down upon me. I fumbled for my lantern, its flickering flame casting eerie shadows on the walls as I made my way deeper into the warehouse. The boxes, I knew, were somewhere in here, waiting for me to uncover their secrets. But what secrets, exactly, I had yet to discover.

es_first_half: Hay algo de lo que estoy satisfecho, sin embargo: que todas las cajas que llegaron a Whitby de Varna, en el Demetrio, estaban depositadas en
es_second_half: la vieja capilla de Carfax. Debía haber allí cincuenta, a menos que hubieran retirado ya alguna…, como lo temía, basándome en el diario del doctor Seward.
es_results: la iglesia de San Miguel, donde se las dejó a cargo del reverendo Patrick Costello, quien las había solicitado expresamente para su custodia. El reverendo
es_results_raw: la iglesia de San Miguel, donde se las dejó a cargo del reverendo Patrick Costello, quien las había solicitado expresamente para su custodia. El reverendo Costello, un hombre de edad avanzada, había sido el encargado de la iglesia durante más de veinte años y era conocido por su integridad y su dedicación al servicio de la comunidad. Sin embargo, al recibir las cajas, se sintió inquieto y preocupado, ya que sabía que contenían algo que podría cambiar el curso de la historia de Whitby de manera drástica. A medida que pasaban las horas, su inquietud se convirtió en una sensación de miedo, y comenzó a preguntarse si había hecho lo correcto al aceptar las cajas.

en_first_half: I came tiptoe into our own room, and found Mina asleep, breathing so softly that I had to put my ear down to hear it. She looks paler than usual. I hope the meeting to-night has not upset her. I am truly thankful that she is to be left out of our future work, and even of our deliberations. It is too great a strain for a woman to bear. I did not think so at first, but I know better now. Therefore I am glad that it is settled. There may be things which would frighten her to hear; and yet to conceal them
en_second_half: from her might be worse than to tell her if once she suspected that there was any concealment. Henceforth our work is to be a sealed book to her, till at least such time as we can tell her that all is finished, and the earth free from a monster of the nether world. I daresay it will be difficult to begin to keep silence after such confidence as ours; but I must be resolute, and to-morrow I shall keep dark over to-night’s doings, and shall refuse to speak of anything that has happened. I rest on the sofa, so as not to disturb her.

en_first_half: 1 October.—It is strange to me to be kept in the dark as I am to-day; after Jonathan’s full confidence for so many years, to see him manifestly avoid certain matters, and those the most vital of all. This morning I slept late after the fatigues of yesterday, and though Jonathan was late too, he was the earlier. He spoke to me before he went out, never more sweetly or tenderly, but he never mentioned a word of what had happened in the visit to the Count’s
en_second_half: house. And yet he must have known how terribly anxious I was. Poor dear fellow! I suppose it must have distressed him even more than it did me. They all agreed that it was best that I should not be drawn further into this awful work, and I acquiesced. But to think that he keeps anything from me! And now I am crying like a silly fool, when I know it comes from my husband’s great love and from the good, good wishes of those other strong men.

es_first_half: 1 de octubre. Me resulta extraño permanecer en la oscuridad, como hoy; después de la confianza total de Jonathan durante tantos años, me resulta desagradable verlo evitar ciertos temas de conversación de manera manifiesta: los temas más vitales de todos. Esta mañana dormí hasta una hora avanzada, a causa de las fatigas de ayer, y aunque Jonathan durmió hasta tarde también, despertó antes que yo. Habló conmigo antes de salir, y nunca antes lo había hecho con mayor dulzura o ternura, pero no mencionó ni una sola palabra sobre lo que había
es_second_half: sucedido en su visita a la casa del conde. Sin embargo, debe saber la terrible ansiedad que sentía yo. ¡Pobre Jonathan! Supongo que eso debe haberlo afligido todavía más que a mí. Todos estuvieron de acuerdo en que no siguiera yo adelante en ese horrible asunto, y estuve de acuerdo. Pero, ¡me resulta muy desagradable pensar que me oculta algo! Y ahora estoy llorando como una idiota, cuando, en realidad, sé que todo esto es producto del gran amor de mi esposo y de la buena voluntad de todos esos hombres fuertes.

en_first_half: “No, sir. But ye needn’t have no difficulty about that. It’s a ’igh ’un with a stone front with a bow on it, an’ ’igh steps up to the door. I know them steps, ’avin’ ’ad to carry the boxes up with three loafers what come round to earn a copper. The old gent give them shillin’s, an’ they seein’ they got so much, they wanted more; but ’e took one of them by the shoulder and was like to throw ’im down the steps, till the lot of them went away cussin’.” I thought that with this description I could find the house, so, having paid my friend for his information, I started off for Piccadilly. I had gained a new painful experience; the Count could, it was evident, handle the earth-boxes himself. If so, time was precious; for, now that he had achieved a certain amount of distribution, he could, by choosing his own time, complete the task unobserved. At Piccadilly Circus I discharged my cab, and walked westward; beyond the Junior Constitutional
en_second_half: I came across the house described, and was satisfied that this was the next of the lairs arranged by Dracula. The house looked as though it had been long untenanted. The windows were encrusted with dust, and the shutters were up. All the framework was black with time, and from the iron the paint had mostly scaled away. It was evident that up to lately there had been a large notice-board in front of the balcony; it had, however, been roughly torn away, the uprights which had supported it still remaining. Behind the rails of the balcony I saw there were some loose boards, whose raw edges looked white. I would have given a good deal to have been able to see the notice-board intact, as it would, perhaps, have given some clue to the ownership of the house. I remembered my experience of the investigation and purchase of Carfax, and I could not but feel that if I could find the former owner there might be some means discovered of gaining access to the house.

I turned onto Berkeley Street, my eyes scanning the buildings for any sign of the house I had been told about. The description of the stone front with a bow on it and the high steps up to the door was etched in my mind, and I was determined to find it. As I walked, I noticed the sound of horse hooves on the cobblestone streets, and the smell of horse manure filled the air. The sun was beginning to set, casting a golden glow over the city, and I quickened my pace, my heart beating faster with anticipation. I had a feeling that I was getting close, and I didn't want to be caught off guard. I turned onto a side street, and my eyes scanned the buildings once more, searching for any sign of the house. And then, suddenly, I saw it - the stone front with a bow on it, just as my friend had described. I felt a surge of excitement and trepidation as I approached the house, wondering what I would find inside. I took a deep breath, and pushed open the large wooden door, my eyes adjusting to the dim light within. The air inside was musty and stale, and I could hear the sound of creaking floorboards beneath my feet. I stepped inside, my heart pounding in my chest, and began to make my way deeper into the house, my eyes scanning the shadows for any sign of the Count or his earth-boxes.

es_first_half: –No, señor. Pero no tendrá dificultades en encontrarla. Es un edificio alto, con una fachada de piedra y un escudo de armas y unas escaleras bastante altas que llegan hasta la puerta de entrada. Recuerdo esas escaleras debido a que tuve que subir por ellas con las cajas, junto con tres muchachos que se acercaron para ganarse unos peniques. El viejo les dio chelines y, como vieron que les había dado mucho, quisieron más todavía, pero el anciano agarró a uno de ellos por el hombro y poco faltó para que lo echara por las escaleras; entonces, todos ellos se fueron, insultándolo. Pensaba que con esos informes no tendría dificultades en encontrar la casa, de modo que después de pagarle a mi informante, me dirigí hacia Piccadilly. Había adquirido una nueva y dolorosa experiencia. El conde podía por lo visto manejar las cajas solo. De ser así, el tiempo resultaba precioso, puesto que ya que había llevado a cabo ciertas distribuciones, podría llevar a cabo el resto de su trabajo, escogiendo el tiempo oportuno para ello, pasando completamente inadvertido. En Piccadilly Circus me
es_second_half: apeé y me dirigí caminando hacia el oeste; después de pasar el junior Constitutional, llegué ante la casa que me había sido descrita y me satisfizo la idea de que se trataba del siguiente refugio que había escogido Drácula. La casa parecía haber estado desocupada durante mucho tiempo. Las ventanas estaban llenas de polvo y las persianas estaban levantadas. Toda la estructura estaba ennegrecida por el tiempo, y de las partes metálicas la pintura había desaparecido. Era evidente que en el balcón superior había habido un anuncio durante cierto tiempo, que había sido retirado bruscamente, de tal modo que todavía quedaban los soportes verticales. Detrás de la barandilla del balcón vi que sobresalían varias tablas sueltas, cuyos bordes parecían blancos. Hubiera dado mucho por poder ver intacto el anuncio, puesto que quizá me hubiera dado alguna indicación en cuanto a la identidad de su propietario. Recordaba mi experiencia sobre la investigación y la compra de la casa de Carfax y no podía dejar de pensar que si podía encontrar al antiguo propietario era posible que descubriera algún medio para entrar en la casa.
es_results: output>encontré un taxi vacío y, después de darle la dirección, me senté en el asiento trasero. El conductor, un hombre de aspecto cansado, me miró por el espejo retrovisor y preguntó: "¿Dónde va, amigo mío?". Le di la dirección del conde y, después de un momento de reflexión, el conductor asintió con la cabeza y dijo: "Sí, conozco ese lugar. Es un edificio antiguo, muy grande y con una fachada impresionante. Pero tenga en cuenta que el conde es un hombre muy reservado y no le gusta que la gente se acerque a su casa sin ser invitada". Me sentí un poco incómodo con esa advertencia, pero el conductor se apresuró a añadir: "No se preocupe, amigo mío, no le haré esperar. Estamos cerca". Me miré alrededor y vi que estábamos en medio de un tráfico intenso, con coches y taxis que se movían en todas direcciones. Me pregunté cómo iba a llegar a mi destino en medio de ese caos. El conductor, como si leyera mis pensamientos, sonrió y dijo: "No se preocupe, amigo mío, estoy en el oficio desde hace muchos años. Sé cómo manejar este tráfico". Me sentí un poco más tranquilo con sus palabras y me quedé callado, observando

Me miré alrededor y vi que estábamos en medio de un tráfico intenso, con coches y taxis que se movían en todas direcciones. Me pregunté cómo iba a llegar a mi destino en medio de ese caos. El conductor, como si leyera mis pensamientos, sonrió y dijo: "No se preocupe, amigo mío, estoy en el oficio desde hace muchos años. Sé cómo manejar este tráfico". Me sentí un poco más tranquilo con sus palabras y me quedé callado, observando el tráfico mientras el conductor se esforzaba por llegar a mi destino. Pasaron varios minutos y el conductor se detuvo en un semáforo rojo. Me miré hacia adelante y vi que estábamos justo enfrente de la casa del conde. Me sentí un poco nervioso, pensando en lo que iba a encontrar allí dentro. El conductor, como si leyera mis pensamientos, se volvió hacia mí y dijo: "¿Está listo, amigo mío?". Asentí con la cabeza y el conductor se apeó del asiento y me ayudó a bajar del taxi. Me miré hacia arriba y vi que la casa del conde era incluso más impresionante de cerca. La fachada de piedra era alta y oscura, con una gran puerta de madera que parecía haber sido tallada con mucho esmero. Me sentí un poco asustado, pero el conductor me dio un golpecito en el hombro y dijo: "No se preocupe, amigo mío, esté tranquilo. El conde es un hombre muy amable". Me miré hacia él y vi que estaba sonriendo. Me sentí un poco más tranquilo con sus palabras y me di cuenta de que estaba listo para enfrentar lo que fuera que me esperara dentro de la casa del conde. Ev, uzun süredir içinde oturulmuyormuş gibi görünüyordu. Pencereleri toz kaplıydı ve kepenkleri açıktı. Tüm çerçeveler zamanla kararmış, demirin üstündeki boyanın çoğu çıkmıştı. Son zamanlara kadar balkonun önünde büyük ilan tabelası olduğu belliydi, ama hoyratça oradan sökülmüştü, tabelayı tutan direkler hâlâ orada duruyordu. Balkon demirlerinin arkasında, cilasız kenarları beyaz görünen bazı gevşek tahtalar gördüm. İlan tabelasını bütün olarak görebilmek için çok şey verirdim, çünkü büyük olasılıkla evin sahibi hakkında bazı ipuçları verirdi. en_first_half: I found all the others at home. Mina was looking tired and pale, but she made a gallant effort to be bright and cheerful, it wrung my heart to think that I had had to keep anything from her and so caused her inquietude. en_second_half: and it smarts dreadfully.” He tried to turn his head; but even with the effort his eyes seemed to grow glassy again so I gently put it back. Then Van Helsing said in a quiet grave tone:—
en_results: The doctor, a middle-aged man with a kind face, looked at me with a mixture of concern and curiosity. He nodded to one of the orderlies, who quickly removed the strait-waistcoat, revealing
en_results_raw: The doctor, a middle-aged man with a kind face, looked at me with a mixture of concern and curiosity. He nodded to one of the orderlies, who quickly removed the strait-waistcoat, revealing a young woman with a pale complexion and a face that was indeed swollen, with dark circles under her eyes. The doctor examined her face more closely, his fingers gently probing the skin around her eyes and cheeks. "You've been ill for some time, haven't you?" he asked softly, his voice a gentle contrast to the sterile, clinical atmosphere of the hospital room. The woman's eyes, though sunken, seemed to hold a deep sadness, and her voice was barely above a whisper as she replied, "I don't know, Doctor. I don't remember anything. Just the dream, and the feeling of being trapped, of being unable to move or speak. It's as if I've been living in a nightmare, and I'm not sure which is reality and which is just a dream." The doctor nodded sympathetically, his expression a mixture of understanding and concern. He made a note on her chart, his brow furrowed in thought. "We'll do some tests, of course," he said, "but in the meantime, I think it would be best if you rest. We'll try to get you comfortable, and see if we can't help you remember what's been happening to you." The woman nodded weakly, her eyes drifting closed as the doctor continued to examine her, his fingers tracing the lines of her face, searching for any clues that might explain the mystery that surrounded her.

en_first_half: “Then,” he looked at me as keenly as he spoke, “all that is in doubt is the conscience of the employer, and the belief of your policemen as to whether or no that employer has a good conscience or a bad one. Your police must indeed be zealous men and clever—oh, so clever!—in reading the heart, that they trouble themselves in such matter. No, no, my friend Jonathan, you go take the lock off a hundred empty house in this your London, or of any city in the world; and if you do it as such things are rightly done, and at the time such things are rightly done, no one will interfere. I have read of a gentleman who owned a so fine house in London, and when he went for months of summer to Switzerland and lock up his house, some burglar came and broke window at back and got in. Then he went and made open the shutters in front and walk out and in through
en_second_half: the door, before the very eyes of the police. Then he have an auction in that house, and advertise it, and put up big notice; and when the day come he sell off by a great auctioneer all the goods of that other man who own them. Then he go to a builder, and he sell him that house, making an agreement that he pull it down and take all away within a certain time. And your police and other authority help him all they can. And when that owner come back from his holiday in Switzerland he find only an empty hole where his house had been. This was all done en règle; and in our work we shall be en règle too. We shall not go so early that the policemen who have then little to think of, shall deem it strange; but we shall go after ten o’clock, when there are many about, and such things would be done were we indeed owners of the house.”

vi_first_half: Ngoài ra, sự thành công của phi vụ còn phụ thuộc vào sự cả tin của các nhân viên cảnh sát khu vực. Nhưng anh bạn Jonathan thân mến ạ, đôi khi anh vẫn có thể dùng móc mở khóa hàng trăm ngôi nhà ở Luân Đôn hoặc ở bất kỳ đâu trên thế giới này mà không sao, miễn là anh tạo ra một hoàn cảnh thích hợp và làm đúng lúc. Tôi có thể kể cho mọi người nghe một câu chuyện mà tôi đã từng đọc. Chuyện là thế này: Có một quý ngài sở hữu một biệt thự tuyệt đẹp ở Luân Đôn. Mùa hè năm đó, do có việc phải đi Thụy Sĩ trong một thời gian khá lâu, khoảng dăm bảy tháng gì đó, ông đã chủ quan khóa cửa nhà trước khi lên đường và chẳng cần nhờ ai trông nom hết. Kết quả là sau khi ông đi được một thời gian ngắn, có kẻ trộm đã đập vỡ kính một ô cửa sổ nhìn ra vườn rồi đột nhập vào trong. Vào nhà rồi, hắn bèn mở tất cả các ô cửa sổ ở mặt tiền của ngôi nhà và đàng hoàng mở cửa chính đi ra ngoài ngay trước mắt đám cảnh sát. Sau đó, hắn công khai rao bán sạch mọi đồ đạc trong nhà bằng một tấm biển quảng cáo to tướng dán trên tường ngoài cổng, hắn đã nhờ một đại diện bán đấu
vi_second_half: giá tới bán tất cả đồ đạc của quý ngài đang ở Thụy Sĩ kia. Thế rồi chính ngôi nhà cũng bị hắn bán tống cho một chủ thầu xây dựng vì hắn đã tìm được giấy tờ sở hữu cất trong nhà. Tay chủ thầu đã bàn với hắn phá bỏ ngôi nhà vào một ngày cụ thể để cất lên một tòa nhà mới. Cảnh sát và chính quyền thành phố cứ tưởng hắn là chủ nhân thật sự của ngôi biệt thự nên đã tạo điều kiện thuận lợi cho hợp đồng xây dựng trao tay này. Chỉ buồn cho người chủ thật sự của ngôi nhà, từ Thụy Sĩ về, trước mắt ông chỉ còn là một cái hố vĩ đại thế chỗ cho ngôi nhà thân quen của ông. Nhưng biết làm sao được, mọi việc đều diễn ra hợp lệ, đúng nguyên tắc mua bán và xây dựng mà thành phố đã quy định. Có lẽ công việc của chúng ta cũng nên tuân theo các nguyên tắc tương tự. Không nên đến Piccadilly quá sớm để tránh sự soi mói của cảnh sát, chỉ có như vậy họ mới không tình cờ để ý thấy sự xuất hiện của chúng ta là không bình thường. Sớm lắm thì cũng chỉ được phép bắt đầu từ mười giờ trở đi, vì khi đó, thể nào người qua lại cũng nghĩ chúng ta chính là chủ nhân thực sự của ngôi nhà.

es_first_half: –Entonces -me miró fijamente, al tiempo que continuaba -, todo lo que estará en duda es la conciencia y la opinión de la policía en cuanto a si es el propietario quien recurrió al cerrajero y la opinión de la policía en cuanto a si el artesano está trabajando o no de acuerdo con las leyes. Su policía debe estar compuesta de hombres cuidadosos e inteligentes, extraordinariamente inteligentes para leer el corazón humano, si es que han de estar seguros de lo que deben hacer. No, no, amigo Jonathan, puede usted ir a abrir las cerraduras de un centenar de casas vacías en su Londres o en cualquier ciudad del mundo, y si lo hace de tal modo que parezca correcto, nadie intervendrá en absoluto. He leído algo sobre un caballero que tenía una hermosa casa en Londres y cuando fue a pasar los meses del verano en Suiza, dejando su casa cerrada, un delincuente rompió una de las ventanas de la parte posterior y entró. Luego se dirigió al frente, abrió las ventanas,
es_second_half: levantó las persianas y salió por la puerta principal, ante los mismos ojos de la policía. A continuación, hizo una pública subasta en la casa, la anunció en todos los periódicos y, cuando llegó el día establecido, vendió todas las posesiones del caballero que se encontraba fuera. Luego, fue a ver a un constructor y le vendió la casa, estableciendo el acuerdo de que debería derribarla y retirar todos los escombros antes de una fecha determinada. Tanto la policía como el resto de las autoridades inglesas lo ayudaron todo lo que pudieron. Cuando el verdadero propietario regresó de Suiza encontró solamente un solar vacío en el lugar en que había estado su casa. Ese delito fue llevado a cabo en régle, y nuestro trabajo debe llevarse a cabo también en régle. No debemos ir tan temprano que los policías sospechen de nuestros actos; por el contrario, debemos ir después de las diez de la mañana, cuando haya muchos agentes en torno nuestro, y nos comportaremos como si fuéramos realmente los propietarios de la casa.

Hayır, hayır, dostum Jonathan, Londranızda ya da dünyanın herhangi bir başka şehrinde yüz boş evin bile kilidini sökseniz ve bu işi olması gerektiği gibi yaparsanız kimse işinize karışmaz. en_first_half: 3-4 October, close to midnight.—I thought yesterday would never end. There was over me a yearning for sleep, in some sort of blind belief that to wake would be to find things changed, and that any change must now be for the better. Before we parted, we discussed what our next step was to be, but we could arrive at no result. All we knew was that one earth-box remained, and that the Count alone knew where it was. If he chooses to lie hidden, he may baffle us for years; and in the meantime!—the thought is too horrible, I dare not think of it even now. This I know: that if ever there was a woman who was all perfection, that one is my poor wronged darling. I love her a thousand times more for her sweet pity of last night, a pity that made my own hate of the monster
en_second_half: seem despicable. Surely God will not permit the world to be the poorer by the loss of such a creature. This is hope to me. We are all drifting reefwards now, and faith is our only anchor. Thank God! Mina is sleeping, and sleeping without dreams. I fear what her dreams might be like, with such terrible memories to ground them in. She has not been so calm, within my seeing, since the sunset. Then, for a while, there came over her face a repose which was like spring after the blasts of March. I thought at the time that it was the softness of the red sunset on her face, but somehow now I think it has a deeper meaning. I am not sleepy myself, though I am weary—weary to death. However, I must try to sleep; for there is to-morrow to think of, and there is no rest for me until....

es_first_half: 3-4 de octubre, cerca de la medianoche. Creí que el día de ayer no iba a terminar nunca. Tenía el deseo de dormirme, con la esperanza de que al despertar descubriría que las cosas habían cambiado y que todos los cambios serían en adelante para mejor. Antes de separarnos, discutimos sobre cuál debería ser nuestro siguiente paso, pero no pudimos llegar a ningún resultado. Lo único que sabíamos era que quedaba todavía una caja de tierra y que solamente el conde sabía dónde se encontraba. Si desea permanecer escondido, puede confundirnos durante años enteros y, mientras tanto, el pensamiento es demasiado horrible; no puedo permitirme pensar en ello en este momento. Lo que si sé es que si alguna vez ha existido una mujer absolutamente perfecta, esa es mi adorada y herida esposa. La amo mil veces más por su dulce piedad de anoche; una piedad que hizo que incluso el odio que le tengo al monstruo pareciera despreciable. Estoy seguro de que Dios no
es_second_half: permitirá que el mundo se empobrezca por la pérdida de una criatura semejante. Esa es una esperanza para mí. Nos estamos dirigiendo todos hacia los escollos, y la esperanza es la única ancla que me queda. Gracias a Dios, Mina está dormida y no tiene pesadillas. Temo pensar en cuáles podrían ser sus pesadillas, con recuerdos tan terribles que pueden provocarlas. No ha estado tan tranquila, por cuanto he podido ver, desde la puesta del sol. Luego, durante un momento, se extendió en su rostro una calma tal, que era como la primavera después de las tormentas de marzo. Pensé en ese momento que debía tratarse del reflejo de la puesta del sol en su rostro, pero, en cierto modo, ahora sé que se trataba de algo mucho más profundo. No tengo sueño yo mismo, aunque estoy cansado… Terriblemente cansado. The dimly lit halls of the old mansion are beginning to stir with the sound of whispered conversations and the soft rustling of silk as the other guests arrive, each one more elegantly dressed than the last. Meanwhile, in the kitchen, the aroma of roasting meats and freshly baked pastries wafts through the air, teasing our senses and building our hunger for the feast to come. As I take my place at the head of the table, I am struck by the sense of nostalgia that washes over me, memories of countless gatherings past flooding my mind like a warm, golden light. The Professor, ever the master of ceremonies, takes his place at the center of the table, a warm smile spreading across his face as he surveys the gathering before him. With a flourish, he raises his glass in a toast, his voice booming through the hall as he welcomes us all to this, our most special of nights.

The more I thought about it, the more my mind began to spin with possibilities. What if she had discovered something about the mysterious stranger who had been seen lurking around the village? What if she had stumbled upon a dark secret that she was too afraid to share with me? I tried to push these thoughts aside, but they lingered in the back of my mind, refusing to be silenced. As the afternoon wore on, I found myself glancing at Mina more and more, searching for any sign that might reveal what was really going on in that head of hers. But her expression remained as calm and collected as ever, giving nothing away. I was at a loss, and I knew that I would have to wait until she was ready to open up to me. The sun was beginning to set, casting a golden glow over the landscape, and I knew that I would have to be patient. But patience was not my strong suit, and I found myself growing more and more restless as the minutes ticked by. I decided to take a walk, hoping that the fresh air and exercise would clear my head and help me make sense of the strange feelings that were swirling inside me. As I strolled through the village, I couldn't help but feel a sense of unease. The trees seemed to loom over me, casting long shadows that stretched and twisted in the fading light. I quickened my pace, my heart beating a little faster with every step. What was going on in Mina's mind, and why was she keeping it from me? I had to know, and I was determined to find out.

The fire had burned down to embers, casting a warm glow over the small cabin, and the sound of the wind outside created a soothing melody that seemed to lull everyone into a peaceful slumber. As I wrote, I couldn't help but think about the challenges we had faced so far and the ones that lay ahead. The terrain had been treacherous, with steep cliffs and raging rivers, but we had managed to overcome them all, thanks to the bravery and determination of my companions. I finished writing and looked up to see that they were all fast asleep, their faces relaxed and their breathing steady. I smiled to myself, feeling a sense of pride and accomplishment at having made it this far. But I knew that we still had a long way to go, and I couldn't let my guard down just yet. I got up quietly and began to prepare a simple meal of dried meat and biscuits, trying not to disturb the others. As I worked, I couldn't help but think about the unknown dangers that lay ahead, and the uncertainty of our fate. But for now, I just focused on getting the food ready and making sure everyone was comfortable and safe. After a few minutes, I called out softly to my companions, telling them that dinner was ready, and they all stirred and sat up, rubbing their eyes and smiling weakly. We ate in silence, savoring the taste of the food and the warmth of the fire. As we finished eating, I suggested that we get some more rest, and they all agreed, grateful for the chance to recharge. We lay down again, this time with full bellies and a sense of hope, and soon fell into a deep and restful sleep.

La habitación estaba en silencio, solo interrumpido por el sonido de sus respiraciones profundas y el susurro de la lluvia que caía afuera. Algunos de ellos comenzaron a roncar, mientras que otros permanecieron despiertos, mirando hacia la oscuridad que se extendía más allá de la ventana. Yo escribía con la cabeza gacha, intentando capturar cada detalle de la noche, cada sonido, cada movimiento. La fatiga y la tristeza parecían haberse apoderado de todos, pero yo sabía que había algo más que estaba sucediendo, algo que no podía ser visto ni oído, algo que solo se sentía. Y así, escribía, con la pluma que parecía tener vida propia, trazando líneas y palabras que intentaban capturar la esencia de la noche, de la desesperanza y de la esperanza que se escondían en el corazón de cada uno de ellos.

es_first_half: 31 de octubre. Llegamos a Veresti por la tarde. El profesor me dice que esta mañana, al amanecer, a duras penas pudo hipnotizarme, y que todo lo que pude decir fue: "oscuro y tranquilo". Ahora está fuera, comprando una calesa y caballos; dice que más tarde tratará de comprar más caballos, de manera que podamos cambiarlos en el camino. Nos quedan todavía ciento diez kilómetros
es_second_half: por recorrer. El paisaje es precioso y muy interesante; si nos encontráramos en diferentes circunstancias, ¡qué encantador resultaría contemplar todo esto! Si Jonathan y yo viajáramos solos por estas tierras, ¡qué placer sería! Podríamos detenernos, veríamos a la gente, aprenderíamos algo sobre ella y llenaríamos nuestras mentes con todo lo pintoresco y el colorido del campo salvaje y hermoso y las personas tan singulares. Pero, ¡ay…!

en_first_half: Later.—Dr. Van Helsing has returned. He has got the carriage and horses; we are to have some dinner, and to start in an hour. The landlady is putting us up a huge basket of provisions; it seems enough for a company of soldiers. The Professor encourages her, and whispers
en_second_half: to me that it may be a week before we can get any good food again. He has been shopping too, and has sent home such a wonderful lot of fur coats and wraps, and all sorts of warm things. There will not be any chance of our being cold.

The Professor then turns to us and says, "I have arranged for us to take the back roads, it will be a longer journey, but we will avoid the main roads where the Count's followers are likely to be lurking. We will have to be careful, as we don't know what we will be facing on the way. The Professor hands me a small bag, "This is for you, it contains a few useful items, including a pocket watch, a compass, and a small pistol. You never know when we might need them." I take the bag, feeling a sense of determination and purpose. The Professor then turns to the others, "Alright, let's get moving, we have a long journey ahead of us. We will have to be quick and quiet, and stay together at all times. We can't afford to lose anyone." The Professor looks at each of us, making sure we understand the gravity of the situation. We all nod in agreement, and the Professor leads us out of the inn, into the darkness of the night.

The road stretches out before us, a long, straight ribbon of asphalt that disappears into the distance, and I can feel the weight of our journey bearing down on me. We've been driving for so long, and I'm starting to feel a sense of unease, a feeling that we're being watched, that unblinking eyes are trained on us from the trees and the hills. I glance over at my companion, but they're lost in thought, their eyes fixed on the road ahead, their face set in a determined expression. I wonder what's going through their mind, what fears and doubts they're struggling to keep at bay. The silence between us is oppressive, heavy with unspoken words and unasked questions. I clear my throat, trying to break the tension, but my voice comes out hoarse and barely audible. "How much farther?" I ask, my voice barely above a whisper. My companion doesn't respond, and I'm left to wonder if they even heard me. The silence stretches out between us, a palpable thing that hangs in the air like a challenge, daring us to speak, to break the spell that's been cast over us. But I'm not sure I'm ready to face what's coming next. The road ahead of us is long and winding, and I'm not sure I'm ready to face what's waiting for us at the end of it.

en_results_raw: As the sun rose higher in the sky, I couldn't help but feel a sense of unease wash over me. The stillness of the room seemed to be suffocating, and the silence was oppressive. I tried to shake off the feeling, telling myself it was just my imagination playing tricks on me, but the sensation lingered. I glanced over at Madam Mina, her peaceful expression a stark contrast to the turmoil brewing inside me. I sat there for what felt like an eternity, my eyes fixed on her tranquil form, wondering if I should try to rouse her again or simply let her sleep. The minutes ticked by, each one feeling like an hour, until I finally decided to get up and pace around the room, trying to clear my head and calm my racing thoughts. As I walked, I couldn't help but think about the events of the previous night, replaying them in my mind like a twisted reel. The strange noises, the eerie feeling of being watched, the sense of being on the brink of something momentous. I stopped pacing and stood by the window, gazing out at the brightening sky, feeling the weight of the unknown pressing down on me. And then, just as I was starting to feel like I was losing my grip on reality, I heard a faint noise coming from the direction of Madam Mina's bed. It was a soft, almost imperceptible sound, but it was enough to make my heart skip a beat. I turned back to her, my eyes scanning her face, and that's when I saw it - a tiny, almost imperceptible movement, a hint of a twitch in her eyelid. She was waking up.
